config.question: What allowed Jim Crow laws to spread across the South at the end of the nineteenth century?

choices.content: Northerners regretted the abolition of slavery.
The federal government was busy with foreign affairs.
African Americans misused their newly found freedom.

answer_3.response: Consider This: Segregation and disfranchisement began as informal agreements in the immediate aftermath of the Civil War. They soon culminated in a legal regime of separation and exclusion that took firm hold in the 1890s. See L.O. 19.3 Why did Jim Crow laws spread across the South after the end of the Reconstruction?
